case_name: Buckingham Carnatic Co. Ltd. v. Venkatiah and Madras Labour Union

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 874 of 1962 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated January 15, 1962, of the Madras High Court in Writ Appeal No. 82 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 874 of 1962. Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 15, 1962, of the Madras High Court in Writ Appeal No. 82 of 1959.

facts.text: The appellant, the Buckingham Carnatic Co. Ltd., is a company registered under the Indian Companies Act with registered office at Madras and a Textile Mill in Madras City employing 14,000 workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, the Buckingham Carnatic Co. Ltd., is a companypany registered under the Indian Companies Act and its registered office is at Madras. It has a Textile Mill in Madras City which employs 14,000 workmen.

facts.text: On January 10, 1957, the respondent Venkatiah went on leave for six days, which expired on January 18, 1957 taking into account intervening holidays.

anchor.surface_text: On January 10, 1957, the respondent Venkatiah whose case is sponsored by the respondent Union, the Madras Labour Union, had gone on leave for six days. Taking into account the intervening holidays, the said leave expired on January18, 1957.

facts.text: Venkatiah did not join duty on January 19, 1957, but remained absent without leave without sending any communication for extending his leave.

anchor.surface_text: He, however did number join duty on the 19th January as he should have, but remained absent without leave without sending to the appellant any companymunication for extending his leave.

facts.text: On March 11, 1957, Venkatiah sent a letter to the appellant stating that after reaching his village near Kanigiri he suffered from fever and dysentery and was treated by the Civil Assistant Surgeon, Kanigiri.

anchor.surface_text: On the 11th March 1957 he sent a letter to the appellant stating that sometime after reaching his village near Kanigiri he suffered from fever and dysentery and was treated by the Civil Assistant Surgeon, Kanigiri.

facts.text: The letter was accompanied by a certificate from Civil Assistant Surgeon stating Venkatiah suffered from chronic malaria and dysentery from January 15 to March 7, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: This letter was accompanied by a certificate issued by the said Civil Assistant Surgeon. In this certificate it was stated that Venkatiah suffered from chronic malaria and dysentery from January 15 to, March 7, 1957.

facts.text: Venkatiah was examined by the Senior Medical Officer of the appellant who was unable to confirm that he had been ailing for nearly two months.

anchor.surface_text: When he appeared before the Manager of the Company, he was asked to go to the Senior Medical Officer of the appellant for examination. The said Officer examined him and was unable to companyfirm that he had been ailing for a period of nearly two months.

facts.text: On March 23, 1957, the appellant informed Venkatiah that he could not be reinstated as his explanation for absence was unsatisfactory.

anchor.surface_text: Acting on that opinion the appellant refused to take back Venkatiah and when Venkatiah pressed to be taken back, the appellant informed him on March 23, 1957 that he companyld number be reinstated as his explanation for his absence was un- satisfactory.

facts.text: Venkatiah's case was treated by the appellant under Standing Order No. 8(ii) of the Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: The case of Venkatiah was treated by the appellant under Standing Order No. 8 ii  of the Standing Orders of the appellant.

facts.text: On or about June 15, 1957, Venkatiah obtained cash sickness benefit for the period covered by the medical certificate from Employees State Insurance Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, Venkatiah had applied to the Employees State Insurance Corporation and on or about the 15th June 1957 he obtained cash sickness benefit for the period companyered by the medical certificate issued. by the Civil Assis- tant Surgeon, Kanigiri.

facts.text: Rs. 82-14-00 were paid to Venkatiah by the Regional Director who accepted the certificate as alternative evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, Rs. 82-14-00 were paid to him.

facts.text: The case was referred for adjudication to the Labour Court at Madras as industrial dispute S.P.O. No. A-5411 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: When the appellant refused to take back Venkatiah in its employment, the respondent Union took up his case and it was referred for adjudication to the Labour Court at Madras as an industrial dispute  S.P.O. No. A-5411 of 1958 .

facts.text: Labour Court rejected appellant's objection on invalidity of reference and held that under Standing Orders appellant was justified but s.73 made refusal illegal, ordered reinstatement without back wages but with continuity of service.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Labour Court the appellant urged that the reference made was invalid and it also companytended that the termination of Venkatiahs services was Justified. The Labour Court rejected the appellants preliminary object-ion about the invalidity of the reference. ... That is why the Labour Court directed the management of the appellant to reinstate Venkatiah within two weeks after its award came into force without liability to pay back-wages, but with companytinuity of service.

facts.text: Appellant filed Writ Petition No. 716 of 1958 in Madras High Court, allowed by Mr. Justice Balkrishna Ayyar who held s.73 inapplicable and award based on sympathy.

anchor.surface_text: After this award was pronounced by, the Labour Court, the appellant moved the Madras High Court by 2 writ petition and prayed that the said award be quashed  W.P. No. 716 of 1958 . This writ petition was allowed by Mr. Justice Balkrishna Ayyar. The learned Judge held that s. 73 of the Act was inapplicable to the present case and found that, in substance, the labour companyrt had made its award on grounds of sympathy for Venkatiah rather than on the merits of the case In the result, the said award was set aside by the learned judge.

facts.text: Respondents filed Letters Patent Appeal No. LPA 82 of 1959, allowed by Division Bench restoring Labour Court award, holding s.73 applies.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the companyrectness of this decision by a Letters Patent Appeal before a Division Bench of the Madras High Court  No. LPA 82 of 1959 . The respondents appeal was allowed by the Division Bench and in companysequence, the award passed by the Labour Court has been restored.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal with certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decision that the appellant has companye to this Court with a certificate issued by the Madras High Court under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Standing Orders revised by arbitration award between parties in 1957.

anchor.surface_text: This Standing Order is a part of the certified Standing Orders which had been revised by an arbitration award between the parties in 1957.

facts.text: Civil Assistant Surgeon certified on March 7, 1957 that Venkatiah suffered from chronic dysentery from January 15 to March 7, 1957 and was fit to join on March 9, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already indicated, the Civil Assistant Surgeon numberdoubt certified on March 7, 1957 that Venkatiah had suffered from chronic dysentery from janu ary 15 to March 7, 1957, and he added that he was then companypletely free from the ailments and was in a fit state of health to join duty on the 9th March 1957.

facts.text: Appellant's Medical Officer examined Venkatiah on March 22, 1957 and was unable to confirm illness for nearly two months.

anchor.surface_text: When Venkatiah was examined by the Medical Officer of the appellant on the 22nd March 1957, thr- Medical Officer was unable to companyfirm that he was ill for a period of nearly two months.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that termination under Standing Order 8(ii) is automatic and not contravention of s.73 as it did not occur during period of illness.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we do number think the High Court was justified in taking the view that the termination of Venkatiahs services under S.O. 8 ii  to which the appellant has given effect by refusing to take him back, companytravenes the provisions of s. 73 1 .

facts.text: Appeal allowed by Supreme Court on August 2, 1963, Division Bench order set aside, Single Judge restored.

anchor.surface_text: August 2, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.- ... In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the Division Bench of the Madras, High Court is set aside and that of the Single Judge restored.

concepts.unlisted_description: Employer not to dismiss or punish employee during period of sickness etc.

anchor.surface_text: Let us first examine Standing Order No. 8 ii before proceeding any further. The said Standing Order reads thus Absent without Leave Any employee who absents himself for eight consecutive working days without Leave shall be deemed to have left the Companys service without notice thereby terminating his contract of service. If he gives an explanation to the satisfaction of the management, the absence shall be converted into leave without pay or dearness allowance. Any employee leaving the Companys service in this manner shall have no claim for re- employment in the Mills. But if the absence is proved to the satisfaction of the Management to be one due to sickness, then such absence shall be converted into medical leave for such period as the employee is eligible with the permissible allowances.

concepts.interpretation: Automatic termination of contract if absent 8 days without leave unless satisfactory explanation; rebuttable by proof of sickness.

anchor.surface_text: Section 73 of the Act reads asunder Employer not to dismiss or punish employee during period of sickness, etc.- No employer shall dismiss, discharge, or reduce or otherwise punish an employee during the period the employee is in receipt of sickness benefit or maternity benefit, not shall he, except as provided under the regulations, dismiss, discharge or reduce or otherwise punish an employee during the period he is in receipt of disablement benefit for temporary disablement or is under medical treatment for sickness or is absent from work as a result of illness duly certified in accordance with the regulations to arise out of the pregnancy or confinement rendering the employee unfit for work. No notice of dismissal or discharge or reduction given to an employee during the period specified in sub-section  1  shall be valid or operative.

concepts.interpretation: Prohibits positive punitive acts by employer during certified sickness period; does not apply to automatic termination under standing order.

issues.text: The principal question which arises in this appeal relates to the true scope and effect of the provisions contained in s. 73 of the Employees State Insurance Act, 1948

anchor.surface_text: The principal question which arises in this appeal relates to the true scope and effect of the provisions contained in s. 73 of the Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 hereinafter called the Act .

issues.text: whether the appellant did not act fairly in rejecting Venkatiahs case that he was ill and in refusing to act upon the certificate produced by him in support of his case

anchor.surface_text: The High Court appears to have taken the view that the appellant did not act fairly in rejecting Venkatiahs case that he was ill and in refusing to act upon the certificate produced by him in support of his case.

issues.text: whether there is any specific provision in the Act which compels the appellant to accept the view taken by the relevant authority under the Act when it decided to give assistance to Venkatiah

anchor.surface_text: This argument is no doubt, prima facie, attractive, but before accepting it, it would be necessary to find out whether there is any specific provision in the Act which compels the appellant to accept the view taken by the relevant authority under the Act when it decided to give assistance to Venkatiah.

issues.text: what is the effect of s. 73(1)

anchor.surface_text: Even so, what is the effect of s. 73(1)? In considering this question, it would be useful to take into account the provisions of sub-s.(2). This sub-section provides that no notice given to an employee during the period specified in sub-s.(1) shall be valid or operative.

issues.text: the question about the true denotation of the word discharge in s. 73(1)

anchor.surface_text: In considering the question about the true denotation of the word discharge in s. 73(1), it is relevant to bear in mind the provisions of S. 85(d) of the Act.

The section merely prohibits any punitive action being taken against the employee during the period of his illness, and he urges that the prohibition is not confined to punitive action in respect of illness alone but extends to punitive action in respect of all kinds of misconduct whatever.

anchor.surface_text: Where termination of the employees services follows automatically either from a contract or from a Standing Order by virtue of the employees absence without leave for the specified period, such termination is not the result of any positive act or order on the part of the employer, and so to such a termination the prohibition contained in s. 73 1 would be inapplicable.

arguments.claim: No inconsistency between s.73 and SO 8(ii)

holdings.text: The termination of Venkatiah's services under Standing Order 8(ii) by refusing to take him back does not contravene section 73(1) of the ESI Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we do number think the High Court was justified in taking the view that the termination of Venkatiahs services under S.O. 8 ii  to which the appellant has given effect by refusing to take him back, companytravenes the provisions of s. 73 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Termination follows automatically from absence without leave under SO 8(ii) without any positive act or order of dismissal/discharge/punishment by employer; s.73 prohibits only such active employer actions during certified illness period.

holdings.text: Standing Order 8(ii) deems an employee who absents for eight consecutive working days without leave to have terminated his contract of service, unless rebutted by satisfactory explanation to management or proof of sickness.

anchor.surface_text: Let us first examine Standing Order No. 8 ii before proceeding any further. The said Standing Order reads thus Absent without Leave Any employee who absents himself for eight consecutive working days without Leave shall be deemed to have left the Companys service without notice thereby terminating his contract of service. ... The certified Standing Orders represent the relevant terms and conditions of service in a statutory form and they are binding on the parties

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of SO 8(ii); certified standing orders binding as statutory terms overriding common law abandonment requiring intention.

holdings.text: High Court not justified in holding that appellant did not act fairly in rejecting Venkatiah's illness claim and certificate.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court appears to have taken the view that the appellant did not act fairly in rejecting Venkatiahs case that he was ill and in refusing to act upon the certificate produced by him in support of his case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Labour Court accepted employer's medical officer's opinion and repelled bias claims; writ jurisdiction under Art.226 does not permit re-appraisal of evidence findings absent mala fides.

holdings.text: High Court could not re-appraise Labour Court's conclusion on medical evidence propriety in writ jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from this aspect, however, we do number see how it was open to the High Court to consider the propriety of the conclusion reached by the Labour Court on this point. We have already noticed that the Labour Court has specifically repelled the criticism made by the respondent against the conduct of the appellants Medical Officer

holdings.reasoning_summary: Writ court defers to tribunal's fact/evidence findings unless perversity or error of law; no mala fides alleged.

holdings.text: No provision compels employer to accept ESI authorities' view on employee's illness for Standing Orders application.

anchor.surface_text: This argument is numberdoubt, prima facie, attractive, but before accepting it, it would be necessary to find out whether there is any specific provision in the Act which compels the appellant to accept the view taken by the relevant authority under the Act when it decided to give assistance to Venkatiah.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ESI Reg.53 allows alternative evidence; no statutory link binding employer under separate SO regime; different purposes.

holdings.text: Section 73(1) ESI Act creates moratorium prohibiting employer from any punitive action (dismissal, discharge, etc.) during period of certified sickness where sickness benefit received.

anchor.surface_text: What s. 73 1  prohibits is such punitive action and it limits the extent of the said prohibition to the period during which the employee is ill. We are free to confess that the clause is number very happily worded, but it seems to us that the plain object of the clause is to put a sort of a moratorium against punitive actions during the pendency of the employees illness.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading aided by s.73(2) invalidating notices during period; applies to all misconduct, not just illness-related; 'receipt of benefit' covers post-illness payment period of illness.

holdings.text: 'Discharge' in s.73(1) denotes employer's positive decision/order, not automatic termination under SO 8(ii).

anchor.surface_text: In considering the question about the true denotation of the word discharge in s. 73 1 , it is relevant to bear in mind the provisions of S. 85 d  of the Act. ... The word discharge in s. 73 1  must,therefore, in the context, be taken to be a discharge which is the result of a decision of the employer embodied in an order passed by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.85(d) penalizes contravening employer; implies active order; distinguishes automatic contractual consequences.

holdings.text: Liberal/beneficent construction for social legislation cannot override plain statutory words or extend beyond reasonable meaning.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Dolia contends that since this Act has been passed for conferring certain benefits on employees in case of sickness, maternity and employment injury, it is necessary that the operative provisions of the Act should receive a liberal and beneficent construction from the court. ... But in dealing with the plea raised by Mr. Dolia that the section should be liberally construed, we cannot overlook the fact that the liberal construction must ultimately flow from the words used in the section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acknowledges purposive approach for welfare statutes but subordinate to textual meaning; cannot strain words.

holdings.text: No inconsistency between s.73 ESI Act and Standing Order 8(ii).
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.73 inapplicable to automatic SO terminations; harmonious operation.

Fact f10 describes Venkatiah obtaining cash sickness benefit based on the medical certificate from ESI Corporation, satisfying Regulation 53's requirement for evidence of sickness.
Fact f10 of obtaining sickness benefit from ESI based on the certificate supports issue i2 regarding fairness in rejecting the certificate as evidence of illness.
Fact f11 states the Regional Director accepted the certificate as alternative evidence and made payment, directly satisfying the proviso in Regulation 53 allowing other evidence.
Fact f11 of payment by Regional Director accepting certificate supports issue i2 on fairness of rejecting Venkatiah's illness claim and certificate.
Fact f11 of ESI Regional Director's acceptance and payment triggers issue i3 on whether employer compelled to accept such authority view for assistance given.

anchor.surface_text: ADKAR, J.-The principal question which arises in this appeal relates to the true scope and effect of the provisions companytained in s. 73 of the Empl

edges.explanation: Holding that termination under Standing Order 8(ii) does not contravene s.73 addresses principal question on scope and effect of s.73 provisions.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we do number think the High Court was justified in taking the view that the termination of Venkatiahs services under S.O. 8 ii  to which the appellant has given effect by refusing to take him back, companytravenes the provisions of s. 73 1 .
In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the Division Bench of the Madras, High Court is set aside and that of the Single Judge restored.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court appears to have taken the view that the appellant did not act fairly in rejecting Venkatiahs case that he was ill and in refusing to act upon the certificate produced by him in support of his case.
In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the Division Bench of the Madras, High Court is set aside and that of the Single Judge restored.

anchor.surface_text: This argument is numberdoubt, prima facie, attractive, but before accepting it, it would be necessary to find out whether there is any specific provision in the Act which compels the appellant to accept the view taken by the relevant authority under the Act when it decided to give assistance to Venkatiah.
In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the Division Bench of the Madras, High Court is set aside and that of the Single Judge restored.

anchor.surface_text: What s. 73 1  prohibits is such punitive action and it limits the extent of the said prohibition to the period during which the employee is ill. We are free to confess that the clause is number very happily worded, but it seems to us that the plain object of the clause is to put a sort of a moratorium against punitive actions during the pendency of the employees illness.
In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the Division Bench of the Madras, High Court is set aside and that of the Single Judge restored.

anchor.surface_text: In considering the question about the true denotation of the word discharge in s. 73 1 , it is relevant to bear in mind the provisions of S. 85 d  of the Act. ... The word discharge in s. 73 1  must,therefore, in the context, be taken to be a discharge which is the result of a decision of the employer embodied in an order passed by him.
In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the Division Bench of the Madras, High Court is set aside and that of the Single Judge restored.
